events.event_description: U.S. coal shipments decreased by 8% in 2023 as coal's share of power generation continued to decline. Coal transport to power plants fell to 422 million tons in 2023, down from 957 million tons in 2010.
events.citation: The amount of coal transported in the United States decreased 8% in 2023, continuing a trend in which coal shipments have generally decreased over the past two decades as coal's share of power generation has declined in the United States. The amount of coal transported to power plants, which are often located far from mines, decreased by more than half, falling from 957 million tons in 2010 to 422 million tons in 2023.

events.event_description: U.S. coal producers shipped 35 million more tons than power plants consumed in 2023, leading to a 48% increase in power plant inventory levels and reduced deliveries in early 2024.
events.citation: During 2023, U.S. coal producers shipped 35 million more tons (9%) than U.S. power plants consumed. Surplus deliveries last year boosted inventory levels at power plants by 48%, reducing deliveries in early 2024.

events.event_description: Coal shipments to power plants in 2021 and 2022 were 59 million tons less than consumption, causing inventories to drop below 100 million tons.
events.citation: Conversely, coal shipments to power plants in 2021 and 2022 were 59 million tons less than the amounts consumed during those two years, and inventories dropped to less than 100 million tons.

events.event_description: Railroads transported nearly three-quarters of all U.S. coal in 2023, with 9% of railroad shipments using a secondary mode of transportation.
events.citation: Railroads transported nearly three-quarters of all U.S. coal in 2023... In 2023, 9% of railroad shipments also used a secondary mode of transportation to reach the destination, such as ships on the Great Lakes, barge, truck, or conveyor belt.
